questions.text: Killian’s dehiscence is situated between?
A 50 year old female presented with Dysphagia and chest pain. Barium image is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) DES -Clinical feature of DES: Chest pain similar to angina ( Normal ECG) and dysphagia -Ix: 1) Barium Swallow: SPASM of circular muscles leading to corkscrew or Rosary Bead appearance of esophagus -2) Manometry: Increase Duration>2.5 sec , Increase Amplitude > 120 mm hg -3) In resolution Manometry: DCI > 450 Hg /sq cm -Management: Medical MX: Nitrates , CCB > If patient does not respond then Myotomy .

questions.text: A newborn baby on 2nd day of life was found to have continuous frothing of saliva from the mouth in the emergency. Identify the pathology in the image given below:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Tracheo esophageal fistula We see the naso gastric tube coiled due to esophageal atresia, we see the gas in the stomach that means there is Tracheo-esophageal fistula.

questions.text: Best investigation for the diagnosis of Gastroesophageal reflux disease?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 24-hour ph monitoring is best investigation that is De Meester criteria Summary IOC: Esophagus •Zenker’s diverticulum: Ba swallow •Stricture: Barium swallow •Webs and rings- Barium swallow •All motility disorders (Achalasia/ Nutcracker esophagus/ DES/ Jackhammer esophagus):- Manometry •Achalasia: Ba Swallow (Gold standard - Manometry) •Esophageal perforation: Barium swallow (to see inflammation and for Pneumomediastinum- CECT is best) •GERD: Gold standard is 24 hrs pH monitoring (De- Meester criteria)

questions.text: The surgeon is doing upper Gl endoscopy. He has crossed the cricopharyngeal sphincter. He saw another indentation in the esophagus. This is related to which of the following?

A female patient with H/O gastrectomy 10 months ago presented for examination of cataract. During examination her tongue was found shiny and smooth (Beefy tongue). Picture given below. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) B12 Def anaemia Beefy tounge is B12 def anaemia due to intrinsic factor def. Folic acid def. – due to decrease HCL

questions.text: A 37 year old female with h/o alcohol intake was taking NSAIDS for abdominal pain. She developed severe pain in the whole abdomen. Radiograph is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Hollow viscus perforation We can see air below diaphragm i.e. Hollow viscus perforation.

questions.text: According to the image given below, obtained from the stomach of a woman, which specialist is needed along with surgeon?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Psychiatrist This is tricobezoar causes Rapunzel Syndrome more common in young females. This is because they eat hair which is psychiatric problem.

questions.text: 35 years old male with gastric outlet obstruction presented to emergency with multiple episodes of vomiting. Which of the following fluid is preferred for this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Normal saline The patient is only loosing HCL with Na+ and K+ i.e. Alkalosis that’s why Normal saline will be preferred because Ringer Lactate will increase Alkalosis.

questions.text: A patient having recurrent vomiting, what kind of acid base imbalance is seen in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Metabolic alkalosis Recurrent vomiting will cause loss of HCL so it will be Metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: A 30 year old lady was incidentally found to have 0.5 cm Gall bladder polyp. What is the best advise for her?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Reassurance and follow up Any polyp 10mm should be taken up for surgery.

questions.text: A 35 year old female presented with right upper abdominal pain. Blood investigations showed Bilirubin 5mg%, Alt 22 IU/L and AST 27 IU/L, ALP was 400 mg%. What should be the next investigation for this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) USG abdomen Bilirubin is raised. We will 1st do USG, if CBD stone go for ERCP. If USG show CBD dilated no stone go for MRCP confirm.

questions.text: A female patient after laparoscopic cholecystectomy presented with cystic duct stump leak What should be the immediate management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) A. Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy: This is a complex surgical reconstruction reserved for severe or complex bile duct injuries. It is not considered first-line management for a cystic duct stump leak, which is usually managed by less invasive means. B. ERCP with stenting: Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) with biliary stenting is the preferred initial treatment. This procedure decompresses the biliary system, reduces the pressure driving the leak, and promotes healing of the cystic duct stump. C. Antibiotics and conservative management: While supportive care, including antibiotics, is important, conservative management alone is typically insufficient when there is an ongoing bile leak. Without addressing the source of the leak, the patient remains at risk for bile peritonitis and other complications. D. Exploratory laparotomy: This invasive surgical intervention is generally reserved for cases where endoscopic management fails or if the patient is unstable with signs of generalized peritonitis. It is not the immediate step for a stable patient with a cystic duct stump leak.

questions.text: According to Bismuth classification, which of the following is type Ill bile duct stricture?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) No length of common hepatic but the junction preserved is TYPE 3

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presented in the emergency with sudden onset of upper abdominal pain radiating to the back with anorexia, nausea and occasional vomiting. Serum amylase was raised. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Acute Pancreatitis Chronic alcoholic, pain radiating to back and serum amylase was raised is suggestive of Acute Pancreatitis.

questions.text: Neuroendocrine tumor of pancreas associated with necrolytic erythema migrans?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Glucagonoma Neuroendocrine tumor of pancreas associated with necrolytic erythema migrans – Glucagonoma It presents with diabetes M. , anaemia, Astomatitis, DVT, Dermatitis.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male had acute appendicitis 3 days ago, now came to surgery department with abdominal tenderness. Which of the following incision is appropriate for this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The incision for appendectomy is 3 can be Grid iron incision which is muscle splitting. No nerve will be injured. Grid iron is converted into Rutherford Morrison incision which is muscle cutting. 2 muscle which we cut in Rutherford Morrison are Int. oblique and transversus abdominis. We don’t cut ext. oblique. 1 nerve which may get injured is Iliohypogastric Nerve.

questions.text: A 3 year old child is brought with history of passage of Greenish yellow fecal discharge from umbilicus. What is most probable embryological cause for this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Fecal discharge means umbilicus is connected to intestine only then we have fecal discharge i.e. Patient Vitello-intestinal duct.

questions.text: A patient was recently operated where laparotomy was done. Patient developed a complication after the operation. What would be the surest sign of wound dehiscence in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Serosanguinous discharge from the wound Salmon pink sign - Serosanguinous discharge from the wound. Serosanguinous discharge comes out from umbilicus on usually 5-8 day.

questions.text: Internal opening of Fistula in Ano is usually found at?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Crypt at dentate line Dentate line have anal crypt connected to anal gland and they get infected and finally a fistula forms.

questions.text: A patient presented in the OPD with serous and pus discharge from the opening in perianal region diagnosed as Fistula in ano. Gold standard investigation for fistula in ano is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) MRI For fistula in Ano Gold standard is MRI.

questions.text: A patient presented with rectal prolapse. On clinical examination there was a growth at the anal verge which is diagnosed as squamous cell carcinoma of the anal verge. Which of the following is the most adequate treatment in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) - The treatment of choice for Squamous cell carcinoma of Anus is Nigro's regime : Combined Chemoradiotherapy for 1 month long . Regimen for chemotherapy is 5FU + Mitomycin/Cisplatin. - After the therapy A) If the tumor resolves completely>Monitoring> 30-40% recurrence > Abdomino Perineal Resection. B) If there is residual tumor > Abdomino Perineal Resection.

questions.text: A 5 year old child was brought o the hospital with H/O constipation since birth. He passes stool once a week after taking laxative. There was a history of passage of meconium > 48 hours after birth. What should be next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Barium enema and manometry Dx: Hirschsprung’s disease Dx: Hirschsprung’s disease (congenital megacolon) Next step will be Barium enema and manometry.

questions.text: Elderly male on DRE was found to have a rectal mass on regular check-up, raising the suspicion of rectal cancer. His bowel habits was otherwise normal. Which of the following should be recommended as the next step to the patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Full colonoscopy and biopsy When we have rectal or colon cancer we do complete colonoscopy.

questions.text: 35 year old male presented with 1 year history of fever anorexia and weight loss. Contrast image of the bowel is given below. What is the possible diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ileocecal TB We can see a stricture in the terminal ileum, string sign is visible, flieschner sign is visible also called inverted umbrella sign found in Ileocecal TB.

choices.text: Hyperextension of neck and look for airway
Large sip of water of fizzy drink to push the food bolus down
5 upper abdominal thrust to force the vomiting

questions.text: 9 year old boy was having dinner with his parents in a hotel room. Suddenly after having dinner he started feeling chocking sensation. Nest step to be done.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Heimlich Manoeuvre For chocking sensation we do Heimlich Manoeuvre. i.e. 5 upper abdominal thrust to force the vomiting.

questions.text: Identify the instrument in the image given below?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Linear stapler This is Linear Stapler which will cut and staple. T A stapler will only cut. Circular stapler – used for end to end enastomosis.

questions.text: A 50 year old patient presented with ascites, pain and tenderness over abdomen. Ascitic fluid showed presence of > 500 Neutrophils/ cmm. What is the best treatment for this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) IV ceftriaxone. WBC > 500, ascites the Dx- Primary spontaneous bacterial peritonitis. T/t by 3rd gen cephalosporins. IV ceftriaxone Main pathogen – E.coli

questions.text: A 48 year old male presented with complains of pain abdomen, vomiting and off and on diarrhoea. His serum serotonin level is high. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Carcinoid History is suggestive of Carcinoid

questions.text: A patient presented with history of bronchospasm. Tumor was present in the ileum with increased 5-hydroxy indole acetic acid in urine. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Carcinoid syndrome It is mentioned that 5-hydroxyl indole acetic acid is high i.e. Carcinoid syndrome.

questions.text: A 35 years old male came to OPD with swelling in left scrotal region and pain, Pain increased on standing and in the evening. On palpation, it feels tike bag of worms. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Varicocele Bag of worms feel is Varicocele. More common on the left side because the left testicular vein drains into left renal vein so it has more anti gravity course. Best Dx. By Dopller and treated by varicocelectomy.

questions.text: A 50 year old male presented with heaviness in scrotum. He suspected cancer and came to OPD. No pain or tenderness was present and transillumination test was negative. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Transillumination test is negative, history is suggestive of Varicocele bag of worms feel is Varicocele. More common on the left side because the left testicular vein drains into left renal vein so it has more anti gravity course. Best Dx. By Dopller and treated by varicocelectomy.

questions.text: Three testis appearance is seen in?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Three testis appearance is seen in Spermatocele. Spermatocele is cystic swelling of epidydemal head, usually unilocular could be bilocular give a Chinese lantern pattern illumination, and it have barley water coloured fluid inside, if we aspirate we get barley water coloured fluid which have spermatozoa. T/t – Sx Dx - USG

questions.text: A 14 years old boy is presented with absent left testis in scrotum. On examination, left testis was Found in superior inguinal pouch. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Ectopic testis This is not the normal path of decent of testis it is ectopic testis if found in any other place other than scrotum. If found in inguinal ring than it would have been undescended testis.

choices.text: Repeatedly bringing the testis down into the scrotum manually

questions.text: A new born baby with empty scrotum was examined and the testis was found to be lying close to superficial ring. Which of the following may help in bringing this testis down?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) GnRh analogue Orchidopexy > GnRh analogue Orchidopexy is done after 6 months for undescended testis.

questions.text: 18 year old boy with sudden onset of pain in right inguino-scrotal area with redness and swelling in scrotum. O/E right testis is pulled up. Dx?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A). Right testicular torsion) Explanation: The clinical presentation of a sudden onset of severe pain in the right inguino-scrotal area, accompanied by redness, swelling in the scrotum, and the finding of a right testis pulled up (high-riding testis) on examination, is highly suggestive of right testicular torsion. This condition occurs when the spermatic cord twists, cutting off blood supply to the testicle. It is a surgical emergency requiring prompt diagnosis and intervention to save the testicle. Incorrect Options: B. Right obstructed hernia Explanation: While an obstructed inguinal hernia can cause pain and swelling in the groin and potentially extend into the scrotum, it typically does not present with a high-riding testis. The pain associated with an obstructed hernia is usually more gradual in onset and may be accompanied by signs of bowel obstruction. C. Right hydrocele Explanation: A hydrocele is a collection of fluid within the tunica vaginalis surrounding the testis. It typically presents as a painless swelling in the scrotum that transilluminates on examination. While there might be a sensation of heaviness or discomfort, sudden severe pain, redness, and a high-riding testis are not characteristic features of a hydrocele. D. Right epididymo-orchitis Explanation: Epididymo-orchitis is an inflammation of the epididymis and testis, often caused by a bacterial infection. It usually presents with a more gradual onset of pain, swelling, redness, and warmth in the scrotum. While the testis might be tender, it is not typically pulled up. Fever and urinary symptoms may also be present.

questions.text: A young male presented with a swelling in the inguinal region as shown in the image given below. Patient did not have any discomfort or pain. He presented for his concern about the swelling. The swelling is reducible and reappears when the patient is asked to cough. Which of the following will be the treatment in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Hernioplasty This is a case of hernia. Herniotomy is only done in children. Hernioplasty is done in adults.

questions.text: 34 year old female with mass in inguinal region which reduces completely on pressure with gurgling sound through deep inguinal ring. Possible diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) This is a case of indirect inguinal hernia. Direct hernia comes out from Hassel back triangle which is bounded by rectus, inferior epigastric artery and inguinal ligament. T/t both by Hernioplasty.

questions.text: A 50 years old male patient presents with palpitations, episodic headache and sweating episodes. Work-up shows small left sided suprarenal mass. Which of the following would be done for confirmation?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) This is a case of Pheochromocytoma Mc presentation – Hypertension Mc overall symptom – headache Confirmation done by – Urinary vanillyl mandelic acid levels

questions.text: A 23 year old male patient presented with hypertension profuse sweating and headache. Which of the following investigation should be done first?

questions.text: A patient presented with increased frequency of mictuirition. On cystoscopy, Pale urethric orifice was seen. Bladder image is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) This is Thimble bladder found in bladder TB. Pale urethric orifice and tubercle around the ureteric orifice is charaterstic of TB bladder.

questions.text: A patient presented in the OPD with hematuria. He has been suffering from recurrent episodes of urinary tract infection. Identify the pathology in the image given below:

questions.text: Which of the following is used for prostate cancer?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Gleason is used for Ca prostate, Bethesda for thyroid, Alvarado for appendix and Nottingham for Breast cancer Gleason score 6-10 6 – well differentiated

questions.text: Managment for a patient presenting with symptoms of Benign Prostatic hyperplasia in the early stages should be?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Tamsulosin For early stage you give alpha 1a blocker And Dutasteride is added when the weight is >40gm

questions.text: 65 year old patient underwent TURP for BPH. Biopsy revealed presence of carcinoma in prostate specimen. Further evaluation showed presence of metastasis too. Which of the following is best treatment for him?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Here it’s a cancer with metastasis Rx- hormone therapy (LHRH agonist) Leuprolide can cause LH surge so it can cause tumor flare initially So it should be combine with Antiandrogen ( Flutamide )

questions.text: An old male having bone secondaries. Most probable site of primary cancer?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Prostate Mc probable site is Prostate

questions.text: Which of the following iodine isotope is used in the management of prostate cancer?

questions.text: Radio-isotope used in thyroid cancer treatment?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) St 89 is used for bone secondary (osteoblast)

questions.text: Most commonly used radio-isotope in PET scan is?

choices.text: Removal of the tumor from the kidney by dissecting through various layers

questions.text: 55 year old lady presented with painless hematuria and swelling in the left flank. On examination a 4cm ballotable mass was felt in the left flank region. Urine cytology was positive for malignant cells. Next line of treatment in this patient should be?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Radical Nephrectomy Ballotable means Kidney Renal cell cancer .

questions.text: A 27 year old patient presented with a renal mass at lower pole with size 7 × 5 × 4 cm. What is the preferred treatment for this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Only upto 4cm – parial nephrectomy If it is at the helium – Total nephrectomy.

choices.text: Treatment is chemotherapy followed by Surgery
It is the commonest intra abdominal malignancy in children

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Nephroblastoma?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Wilms tumor it not spread by Lymphatics. >2 yrs it most common in intra abdominal malignancy in children Most common abdominal lump in neonates – multicystic dysplastic kidney 2nd is PUJ obstruction and hydronephrotic kidney Mc kidney tumor in neonate – mesoblastic nephroma 2yrs – wilms tumor

questions.text: In a worker of dye industry which is the most common cancer?
Most common type of renal stone?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Calcium oxilate dehydrate Monohydrate is very hard and rare stone

questions.text: 5 year old girl presented with continuous dribbling but she is having normal voiding also. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Ectopic ureter

questions.text: A 30 year old male presented with scrotal mass. In biochemical evaluation LDH was found high while BhCG and AFP were normal. Histology is given. What is the most probable diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) AFP is never high in Seminoma but BhCG can be high in 10% of seminoma LDH is a marker for Seminoma. AFP is high is yolk sac tumour and other tumour

questions.text: A 40 year old male presented with testicular swelling and a mass on left side of neck. He observed a nodule in umbilical area too. What is the post probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Mass on left side of neck is virchows node. Nodule in umbilical area is sister mary joseph’s nodule, found in testicular tumor.

choices.text: Involvement of para aortic lymph nodes

questions.text: 60 year old male is diagnosed with testicular cancer. Which of the following is true about spread of testicular tumor?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Involvement of para aortic lymph nodes This is a case of testicular cancer. Testicular cancer goes to para aortic lymph nodes, they don’t go to obturator or inguinal lymph nodes. The prostate and bladder cancer goes to obturator and internal iliac node.

questions.text: Which of the following is the preferred treatment for muscle invasive bladder cancer?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Preferred T/t for muscle invasive bladder cancer is Radical Nephrectomy (removal of prostate,seminal vesicle, bladder)

choices.text: Treatment is to provide scrotal support
Treatment is to wait and watch
Testis are preserved in this pathology

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the pathology shown in the image given below?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Patient is having necrosis of the scrotum i.e. Fournier’s gangrene. It develops synergistic infection Gm +ve and Gm –ve The testis is never removed the tunica albuginea acts as a barrier so testis is always preserved in Fournier’s gangrene.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in all kinds of shock?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Reduced tissue perfusion Shock is defined as a systemic state of low tissue perfusion that is inadequate for normal cellular respiration.

questions.text: A man came with complaints of recurrent discharge and pain due to lesions around the anus for 3 years. A diagnosis of fistula-in-ano is made. What is the gold standard investigation for this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) MRI MRI is the gold standard investigation for fistula-in-ano. It helps us identify secondary extensions of the track, which when missed may cause persistence of the fistula.

questions.text: Which of the following will not have bilateral hydronephrosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Retrocaval ureter Retrocaval ureter is a developmental anomaly of the inferior vena cava (IVC). This anomaly always occurs on the right side, as this is the side of the normal IVC. Hence it does not lead to bilateral hydronephrosis.

choices.text: Penetrating injury to the eustachian tube- CSF otorrhea
Penetrating injury to eye- Battle sign

questions.text: Four patients were brought to the casualty after sustaining trauma. Which of the following is the correct match among the following?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Gaze paresis- midbrain lesion Traumatic injury to the brain affecting the mid-brain or brainstem dysfunction produces: -Gaze paresis -Dysconjugate gaze -Roving eye movements Battle sign and CSF rhinorrhea are features of a middle cranial fossa fracture.

questions.text: While doing an endoscopy, constriction is felt at the oesophageal junction at 25cm from the incisor. This is due to?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Arch of aorta Normally esophagus shows 3 constrictions at the following levels measured from upper incisors: • Cricopharynx (15cm from the incisor teeth) • Arch of aorta and left bronchus (25cm from the incisor teeth) • Diaphragmatic opening (40cm from the incisor teeth)

questions.text: A 17 year old woman with no comorbidities presents with numbness and paraesthesia of the fingers along with the characteristic finding as shown in the image below. She has no history of smoking or history of other illnesses. She mentions that these episodes occur when she is under excess stress or during cold temperatures. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Raynaud’s phenomenon Raynaud’s phenomenon- Episodic digital ischemia due to the vasospasm of digital arteries. Cold exposure or emotional stress can trigger it. Types of Raynaud’s: 1. Primary/Idiopathic 2. Secondary associated with other diseases like Scleroderma, SLE, Rheumatoid arthritis, etc.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of qSOFA score?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) LDH qSOFA assigns one point for each component and suggests potential life-threatening sepsis when atleast 2 of the following parameters are met: • Altered mental status (GCS or equal to 22 breaths/min

questions.text: Which is the least commonly used graft for coronary artery bypass graft (CABG)?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Intercostal artery The left Internal mammary artery (LIMA) provides long-lasting results in a coronary artery bypass graft (CABG). The conduit with the highest patency rate is the left Internal mammary artery or internal thoracic artery.

questions.text: Which of the following is the recommended treatment for the condition shown in the image?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ureteroscopy The given X-ray image shows a lower/distal ureteric stone. Ureteroscopic removal is generally preferred for stones <6mm and specifically those present in the distal ureter. PCNL is mainly used for treating large stones in the renal pelvis and calyces and stones in the proximal ureter. ESWL is used for treating renal calculi. Wait and watch is done for small stones <5mm as they are more likely to pass spontaneously.

questions.text: Which type of graft is depicted in the image shown below?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Autograft The given image shows a split skin graft obtained from the same person. This type of graft is autograft. The most preferable donor site is the buttocks. The most commonly used donor site is the thigh.

questions.text: Which of the following is the class of shock where urine output is first decreased?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Moderate Class 2 is mild, Class 3 is moderate, and Class 4 is severe.

questions.text: A 28 year old mother presents with pain in her left breast. Which of the following is the most likely cause of acute mastitis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Crack in the nipple Acute mastitis is caused by a local bacterial infection when the breast is most vulnerable due to cracks and fissures in the nipples.

questions.text: Involvement of which of the following structures leads to the clinical presentation a shown in the image?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Superficial lymphatics Peau d’orange appearance of the breast occurs due to blockade of superficial lymphatics. The dermal lymphatic blockade gives rise to edema in the breast. The sweat glands and hair follicles get buried due to the edema resulting in a typical orange peel appearance.

choices.text: Breast cancer diagnosed in a postmenopausal female> 50 years of age

questions.text: Genetic testing for BRCA1/ BRCA 2 is indicated for all of the following except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Breast cancer diagnosed in a postmenopausal female> 50 years of age Genetic counselling and testing for genetic mutations are recommended for high-risk women with: • Breast cancer diagnosed before age 50 • Triple negative breast cancer • Family history of two or more individuals with breast and ovarian cancer • A close male relative with breast cancer

questions.text: A 51-year-old lady presents with complaints of a mass in the right breast. On examination, the mass was larger than 2 cm and ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes were present. What is the stage, considering the mass is malignant?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) cT4N1M0 Inflammatory breast carcinoma (stage T4) is an aggressive form of locally advanced breast cancer (LABC) and is associated with the worst prognosis among all subtypes of breast cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a superior mediastinal tumor?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Lymphoma Lymphomas are not tumors of the superior mediastinum. They are tumors of the anterior mediastinum.

questions.text: A 32 year old patient who is a chronic tobacco chewer presents with a whitish lesion on the gingivobuccal sulcus for 7 months. What is the next best step in the management of this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Local excision and biopsy Leukoplakia is a premalignant condition of the oral cavity characterised by whitish patches that involve large areas of the oral mucosa. The next best step in management is local excision and biopsy.

questions.text: A 50 year old woman after thyroidectomy comes to you for 2nd opinion for further treatment of papillary thyroid cancer. What would you recommend for this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Radioiodine scan A radioiodine scan will be recommended to this patient following thyroidectomy, to look for residual or metastatic disease. A positive whole-body iodine scan after total thyroidectomy indicates that there is either a metastatic or residual disease present. These patients are treated with I131 for radio-iodine ablation.

questions.text: Which of the following procedures has maximum risk of recurrence of duodenal ulcers?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Highly selective vagotomy HSV retains the vagal innervation to the antrum, pylorus and the remaining abdominal viscera while cutting off the vagal nerve supply to the proximal 2/3rds of the stomach which houses nearly all of the parietal cells. As a result, HSV has not had a great success treating type 2 and type 3 gastric ulcers as a result of hypergastrinemia brought on by prolonged antral stasis and gastric outlet obstruction.

choices.text: Caused by hypertrophy of longitudinal muscles
USG is very sensitive in diagnosig this condition

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about CHPS?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A. Presents with bilious vomiting – False (Correct Answer) CHPS is non-bilious projectile vomiting. Reason: The obstruction is proximal to the ampulla of Vater, where bile enters the duodenum. So bile cannot be present in the vomitus. Therefore, this statement is not true, making A the correct answer. B. Caused by hypertrophy of longitudinal muscles – True This is a commonly misunderstood point. CHPS primarily involves hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the circular muscle layer. But it can also involve some hypertrophy of longitudinal fibers, although the main pathology is in the circular muscle. So while this statement isn't entirely precise, it is not completely false either. In most academic and exam settings, this is considered a true statement. C. USG is very sensitive in diagnosing this condition – True Ultrasound is the diagnostic tool of choice, with high sensitivity and specificity. It typically shows thickened pyloric muscle (>3mm) and elongated pyloric canal (>15-18mm). D. Hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis seen – True Due to persistent vomiting of gastric acid (rich in H? and Cl?), CHPS leads to hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: Patient presented with sudden onset tearing type of chest pain radiating to the back, shortness of breath and nausea. CT chest image is given. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

Atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory disease in which there is build up of plaques inside arteries. It is common after age 50

A patient suffered from Road traffic accident and brought to the emergency where on examination his GCS was E2M4V2. CT Scan showed the following image. Preferred Rx in this patient should be
Which fluid is used most commonly during intraoperative blood loss?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Normal saline (0.9% sodium chloride) has historically been, and continues to be, one of the most commonly administered intravenous fluids globally in various clinical settings, including during intraoperative blood loss. Its widespread availability, relatively low cost, and long-standing familiarity among clinicians contribute to its frequent use as an initial fluid for volume resuscitation. Despite growing evidence and preferences in some guidelines for balanced electrolyte solutions to mitigate risks like hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis with large volumes, Normal saline still accounts for a very significant portion of crystalloid fluid administration in surgical settings worldwide. Reasons for Incorrect Responses: A. Balanced electrolyte solution: While increasingly preferred and recommended by many modern guidelines due to their more physiological electrolyte composition, balanced electrolyte solutions (e.g., Lactated Ringer's, Plasma-Lyte) have not yet completely overtaken Normal saline in terms of sheer volume and frequency of use globally, especially considering diverse healthcare resource settings. B. Colloids: Colloids (e.g., albumin, starches) contain larger molecules that primarily stay in the intravascular space. While effective for volume expansion, they are generally more expensive, have potential side effects (like renal injury with some synthetic colloids), and are not the initial or most commonly used fluid for general intraoperative blood loss compared to crystalloids. Their use is typically reserved for specific indications or after initial crystalloid resuscitation. C. Blood: Blood products (e.g., packed red blood cells) are the definitive treatment for significant blood loss leading to anemia and impaired oxygen delivery. However, they are administered only when specific transfusion triggers are met (e.g., substantial blood loss, hemoglobin levels falling below a certain threshold, signs of tissue hypoperfusion). They are not the initial or most common fluid given for all or minor to moderate intraoperative blood loss. Crystalloids are almost always used first for initial volume replacement.

questions.text: Patient presented with RTA, brought to ER, with Pulse rate of 120/min, SBP < 80 mm of Hg. He was being managed with IVF, BT but in vain. On exploratory laparotomy, profuse amount of bleeding is there. What should be the management to control massive liver bleed as shown?

A patient whose Kidney stones were removed earlier, presented after 2 years with complaints of fever and flank pain. Imaging done is shown here. What would be the next line of treatment in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Cystoscopic retrieval of FB. The X-ray image clearly shows a double-J ureteral stent, characterized by the "pigtail" coil in the bladder. The patient's symptoms of fever and flank pain, occurring two years after initial kidney stone removal, strongly suggest a complication related to this retained foreign body, such as encrustation, stone formation on the stent, or infection. Cystoscopic retrieval is the standard and least invasive method for removing ureteral stents. This procedure involves inserting a cystoscope (a thin, lighted tube with a camera) through the urethra into the bladder to directly visualize and grasp the stent for removal. Leaving the foreign body inside (Option C) is not an acceptable medical practice due to the high risk of severe complications. Laparotomy (Option A) is an overly invasive surgical approach, and lithotripsy (Option D) is used for breaking stones, not for the primary removal of an intact stent, though it might be used to fragment stones that have formed on the stent as part of the overall management.

questions.text: A patient after Road traffic accident suffered from chest trauma. Tube thoracostomy done which drained 1800 ml of blood in one hour. What will be next management?
Elderly diabetic with extremely painful, blister, woody surface:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A. Necrotising fasciitis: This is a severe, rapidly progressing bacterial infection that involves the fascia, the tissue covering muscles. It is characterized by intense pain (often disproportionate), swelling, skin discoloration, bullae (blisters), and crepitus (gas in tissues, though not always present early). The affected area can feel indurated or "woody" due to deep tissue swelling and inflammation. It is common in diabetics. This aligns very well with all the described symptoms. B. Gas gangrene (Clostridial myonecrosis): This is a life-threatening infection, usually caused by Clostridium species, that primarily affects muscle tissue (myonecrosis). It's characterized by rapid progression, severe pain, edema, bronze skin discoloration, crepitus (due to gas production in tissues), and often a foul-smelling discharge. While it causes severe pain and can involve blisters, the "woody surface" might be less typical compared to the more overt crepitus and muscle necrosis. However, it's a very severe soft tissue infection to consider in a diabetic. C. Cellulitis: This is a common bacterial infection of the dermis and subcutaneous tissue. It causes redness, swelling, warmth, and pain. While it can be painful and spread, it typically does not cause the "extremely painful" disproportionate to appearance, the characteristic "blisters" (unless very severe), or the "woody surface" that suggests deep fascial involvement. D. DVT (Deep Vein Thrombosis): This is a blood clot in a deep vein. Symptoms include swelling, pain, warmth, and redness in the affected limb. While it can cause swelling and pain, it does not typically cause blisters, disproportionate pain to touch, or a "woody" induration of the superficial tissues.

choices.text: Based on infrared emitted from RBC's

questions.text: Which of the following is correct for this device as shown
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Measure systolic blood pressure A. Based on infrared emitted from RBC's: Vascular Dopplers operate using ultrasound waves, not infrared. They detect the shift in frequency of these sound waves as they bounce off moving red blood cells (RBCs) to measure blood flow. Therefore, this statement is incorrect. B. Localise calcified plaque: While Doppler ultrasound can help in assessing blood flow characteristics around plaques, and some advanced ultrasound systems can image plaques, a basic vascular Doppler's primary function is not to directly "localize calcified plaque" as an imaging tool. Its main purpose is to detect and measure blood flow. Therefore, this statement is incorrect as its primary function. C. Measure systolic blood pressure: Correct. Vascular Dopplers are commonly used to non-invasively measure systolic blood pressure, especially in situations where standard auscultatory methods are difficult (e.g., in patients with weak pulses, very low blood pressure, or in specific anatomical locations like the ankle for ABI calculation). The Doppler probe detects the arterial blood flow as the cuff pressure is released, indicating the systolic pressure. D. Check thickness of artery/ vein: Measuring the thickness of an artery or vein wall requires a B-mode (2D imaging) ultrasound machine, which provides detailed anatomical images. A basic vascular Doppler, as shown, primarily uses continuous or pulsed wave Doppler to detect and measure blood flow, not to image tissue thickness. Therefore, this statement is incorrect.

Identify the needle given in the image:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) A. Spinal anaesthetic needle: Spinal needles are typically very thin and sharp, with a short bevel or pencil point, and do not have the spring-loaded safety mechanism seen in the image. B. Epidural anaesthetic needle: Epidural needles (like Tuohy needles) are longer and larger bore than spinal needles, with a curved tip, but they also lack the spring-loaded safety mechanism. C. Veress needle: A Veress needle is specifically designed for gaining access to the peritoneal cavity during laparoscopic procedures. Its key feature is a spring-loaded, blunt inner stylet that retracts when resistance is met (e.g., passing through the abdominal wall) and then springs forward once the peritoneum is entered, providing a safety mechanism against visceral injury. The needle in the image perfectly matches the description and appearance of a Veress needle. D. Optic trocar: An optic trocar is a larger instrument used in laparoscopic surgery to create an entry point for the laparoscope. It's typically much thicker than the needle shown and often has an optical component or a sharp tip with a separate obturator, not the spring-loaded blunt stylet of a Veress needle

questions.text: 60 year old anaemic man who is a smoker presented in OPD for his concern regarding his fatigue as his sister had endometrial cancer. Which should be used for screening in this patient for colorectal malignancy
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) For this 60-year-old anemic man, colonoscopy is the most appropriate and comprehensive diagnostic and screening tool for colorectal malignancy among the given options. The presence of anemia, particularly in a male, is a significant red flag for potential gastrointestinal bleeding, and colorectal cancer must be ruled out as a cause. Colonoscopy allows for direct visualization of the entire colon, identification of any bleeding sources, detection of polyps (which can be precursors to cancer), and immediate biopsy or removal of suspicious lesions. Furthermore, his sister's endometrial cancer raises suspicion for a hereditary cancer syndrome like Lynch Syndrome, which significantly increases the risk of colorectal cancer throughout the entire colon and necessitates a full colon examination. While the "every 10 years" interval is typically recommended for average-risk individuals, for a symptomatic patient like this with anemia and elevated risk factors, a diagnostic colonoscopy would be immediately indicated. Subsequent surveillance intervals would then be tailored based on the findings (e.g., number/type of polyps) and whether a hereditary syndrome is confirmed, likely leading to much shorter intervals than 10 years. However, in terms of the type of procedure that is most effective for evaluating colorectal cancer in this scenario, colonoscopy is the gold standard. Reasons for Incorrect Responses: A. Flexible Sigmoidoscopy yearly: Flexible sigmoidoscopy only examines the lower part of the colon (rectum and sigmoid colon). It would fail to detect cancers or precancerous polyps located higher up in the ascending or transverse colon, which is a significant limitation for a patient with anemia (suggesting potential bleeding from anywhere in the GI tract) and a family history that increases risk throughout the entire colon. C. Barium enema: This is an outdated radiological imaging technique for colorectal evaluation. It is significantly less sensitive than colonoscopy for detecting small polyps and early cancers, and crucially, it does not allow for biopsy or removal of any suspicious lesions found. Modern guidelines rarely recommend barium enema as a primary screening or diagnostic tool for colorectal cancer due to the superiority of colonoscopy. D. Check for occult blood in stool: Fecal occult blood tests (FOBT) or fecal immunochemical tests (FIT) are screening methods designed to detect hidden blood in the stool of asymptomatic, average-risk individuals. This patient is already symptomatic with anemia, implying overt (though perhaps not macroscopically visible) blood loss. In such a case, using a screening test for occult blood is insufficient and inappropriate, as it would delay the necessary direct visualization (colonoscopy) to identify the source of bleeding and diagnose any underlying malignancy.

A lady presented with redness and Peau de orange appearance involving more than 2/3 of breast without any palpable lump in the breast. As per TNM staging of breast cancer which of the following is correct for this lady.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Explanation: The description of "redness and Peau de orange appearance involving more than 2/3 of breast without any palpable lump" is the classic presentation of Inflammatory Breast Cancer (IBC). According to the TNM (Tumor, Node, Metastasis) staging system for breast cancer, Inflammatory Breast Cancer is specifically classified as T4d, regardless of the tumor size or the presence of a palpable mass. This T classification denotes the unique and aggressive nature of this type of breast cancer, which primarily manifests through diffuse skin changes rather than a discrete lump. Incorrect Options: Option A. T4a Explanation: T4a describes a tumor that has extended to the chest wall (excluding only the pectoral muscle). The lady's presentation does not mention involvement of the chest wall. Option B. T4b Explanation: T4b refers to a tumor with skin involvement such as ulceration, satellite nodules, or edema/peau d'orange involving less than one-third of the breast. While "peau d'orange" is mentioned, T4b is for less than one-third involvement, and more importantly, the defining characteristic of "inflammatory breast cancer" (which this presentation strongly suggests due to the extensive involvement) supersedes this sub-classification and directly leads to T4d. Option C. T4c Explanation: T4c is a combination of T4a and T4b, meaning the tumor exhibits both chest wall invasion and skin involvement. Since the lady's symptoms do not align with either T4a or the full definition of T4b (due to the extent of involvement and likely diagnosis of IBC), T4c is incorrect.

The given image is of ulcer, identify marked structure ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Margin – The outermost limit of the ulcer, where normal skin or mucosa meets the ulcer. Edge – The part between the margin and the floor, often sloping or punched out; its character can help in diagnosis (e.g., sloping edge in benign ulcers, undermined in tuberculosis, rolled in carcinoma). Floor – The exposed surface of the ulcer inside, which may be covered with slough or granulation tissue. Base – The part of tissue beneath the ulcer, often felt during palpation; may be hard (indurated) in malignancy or soft in benign ulcers.

questions.text: Trophic ulcer are caused by all except?
Identify the type of ulcer?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The image shows ulcers located on pressure-bearing areas of the foot (heel and sole), with a punched-out appearance and surrounding thickened skin, which are characteristic features of trophic ulcers. These ulcers are typically caused by neuropathy, particularly in conditions like leprosy or diabetes, where the protective sensations are lost. The patient continues to apply pressure or trauma to the area unknowingly, leading to ulcer formation. A. Arterial ulcer is incorrect because arterial ulcers are typically located on the toes, lateral malleolus, or pressure points, and are associated with features like cold, pale feet and absent pulses. They have a punched-out appearance but are usually painful and occur due to poor blood supply. B. Venous ulcer is incorrect because venous ulcers are usually found on the medial aspect of the lower leg, especially near the medial malleolus. They are associated with varicose veins, edema, and hyperpigmentation due to chronic venous insufficiency. D. Diabetic ulcer is incorrect as a general term because while trophic ulcers can occur in diabetes due to peripheral neuropathy, the more accurate term when referring to this specific ulcer pattern (on pressure points with loss of sensation) is trophic ulcer.

Identify level of lymphnode in neck marked ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Level II The star in the provided image is strategically placed in the upper part of the neck, anterior to the sternocleidomastoid muscle, and superior to the hyoid bone, approximately at the level of the angle of the mandible. This anatomical region precisely corresponds to Level II lymph nodes, also known as the upper jugular nodes. These nodes are situated along the upper third of the internal jugular vein, extending from the base of the skull inferiorly to the level of the hyoid bone (or the carotid bifurcation). Level II is a critical drainage basin for lymphatic fluid from various structures of the head and neck, including the nasopharynx, oropharynx (e.g., tonsil, base of tongue), hypopharynx, larynx, and parotid gland. Due to their significant role in draining these areas, Level II nodes are frequently involved in metastatic spread from head and neck cancers, making their accurate identification crucial for staging and treatment planning in oncology. Incorrect Options: B. Level Ia Level Ia refers to the submental lymph nodes. These nodes are located in the submental triangle, beneath the chin and between the anterior belly of the digastric muscles. The marked star is significantly superior and lateral to this region, making Level Ia an incorrect identification. C. Level Ib Level Ib encompasses the submandibular lymph nodes. These nodes are situated in the submandibular triangle, inferior to the body of the mandible. While closer to the marked area than Level Ia, the star is placed higher and more posteriorly, distinctly outside the typical boundaries of the submandibular triangle, thus making Level Ib an incorrect choice. D. Level IV Level IV designates the lower jugular lymph nodes. These nodes are found along the lower third of the internal jugular vein, extending from the level of the cricoid cartilage (or the inferior border of Level III) down to the clavicle. The star in the image is positioned much higher in the neck, far superior to the cricoid cartilage and clavicle, which definitively rules out Level IV.

questions.text: Which of the following is primary use of the imaging modality shown below?
A patient with diffuse severely contaminated peritonitis underwent laparotomy and was left open after surgery which of the following might help?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) VAC (Vacuum-Assisted Closure): Also known as Negative Pressure Wound Therapy (NPWT), VAC is a highly effective and commonly used method for managing open abdominal wounds, especially in cases of severe contamination or peritonitis. It works by applying continuous or intermittent negative pressure to the wound bed, which helps to remove exudate and infectious material, reduce edema, promote the formation of healthy granulation tissue, protect the exposed viscera, and facilitate eventual delayed fascial closure or skin coverage. This technique is crucial for source control and preparing the abdominal cavity for subsequent closure in a staged manner. Incorrect Options: B. Normal saline-soaked gauze: While normal saline-soaked gauze can be used for basic wound dressing and moistening, it is generally considered a less effective and more labor-intensive method for managing large, highly contaminated open abdominal wounds compared to advanced techniques like VAC. It requires frequent dressing changes and does not offer the same benefits in terms of active fluid removal, reduction of abdominal wall tension, or promotion of granulation tissue. C. Prefer closure after laparotomy: In cases of "diffuse severely contaminated peritonitis," immediate primary fascial closure after the initial laparotomy is often contraindicated. This is because it can lead to increased intra-abdominal pressure (abdominal compartment syndrome), persistent infection, and a high risk of anastomotic leak or dehiscence. The abdomen is intentionally left open to allow for repeated assessments, debridements, lavages, and to manage ongoing sepsis, often referred to as "open abdomen management." Therefore, preferring immediate closure would be an inappropriate management strategy in this specific, severe context. D. None of the above: Since VAC therapy is a well-established and beneficial treatment for this clinical scenario, this option is incorrect.
